ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned the logistics and theory behind designing and carrying out psychology experiments.
I learned a lot about writing psych papers.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Professor Hirsch is a great lecturer but way too detailed with grades which adds a huge unnecessary stress to the class.

Strengths: Lots of group work (this could be a weakness for some). High level of engagement. High level of instructor feedback. Weaknesses: Assignments due almost every single class for the first half of the semester, and at least weekly in the second half. This could be a strength for some people in that you never have a ton of work to do at once because it is broken down into lots of small stages that are submitted every few days instead of all at once.

The major strength of this class was honestly professor Hirsch. She truly cares about her students and was always available and willing to help. The class is a bit fast paced. To anyone taking this class, I'd recommend doing the inquizitive quizzes in your first week to ease to load for the rest of the semester - that was what I did and it still felt like a lot was going on in the class.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: No, but it's required for the major so here we are...
Yes! If you do, you should definitely consider taking it with professor Hirsch.
